Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Emergency restraint
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4160
Section (1) The use of emergency restraint as a lifesaving response for a
Description youth will be limited to:
(a) An emergency response to protect the youth or others from
an unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior that places the
youth or others at serious threat of violence or injury if no
immediate intervention occurs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Two unwarranted restraints occurred at the facility.
2

Investigation Restraint 1:
Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/20/2024. Youth A reported he did not recall many of the details
about the restraint in the parking lot. Youth A reported he
“blacked out”. Youth A did not recall why he was mad or what
staff were with him. Youth A recalled throwing rocks however was
unsure what he was specifically throwing rocks at. Youth A did
not recall what happened previously while in school before he
went out to the parking lot. Youth A reported he remembered he
was throwing rocks and a staff restrained him. The restraint
lasted one to two minutes. Youth A was released from the
restraint and returned to the school building. Youth A reported he
did not have any concerns with the restraint and stated, “there
were no marks, scratches, and nothing hurt after.” Youth A
reported he was restrained for throwing rocks. Youth A reported
he has thrown rocks previously on two occasions at cars at the
facility and broke one car window. Youth A denied being
assaultive toward staff in the parking lot prior to being restrained.
Youth A denied pushing or hitting any staff while in the parking lot.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/20/2024. Restraint in the parking lot: Staff 1 reported Youth A
was having issues in school as a peer Youth A says he is dating
was restrained in the school which escalated Youth A. Youth A
approached Staff 7 and began punching Staff 7 in the face three
to four times and Youth A was placed in a restraint. After Youth A
was released from the restraint, Youth A walked willingly out of the
school. Staff 1 went outside approximately five minutes after
Youth A exited the school. Youth A was outside talking with Staff
2, Staff 3, and Staff 4. Staff 1 noticed the conversation with Youth
A, Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4 was increasingly getting louder and
Staff 1 heard sounds that he thought were rocks hitting cars. Staff
1 heard Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4 giving Youth A prompts that
included “you don’t need to do that”, and “stop throwing rocks”.
Staff 1 started to head over to where Youth A was and saw Youth
A grab a handful of rocks. Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4 all initiated
a restraint with Youth A however the restraint was unsuccessful as
Youth A pulled his arms away. Staff 1 reported Youth A has
broken staff car windows previously. Youth A began “throw air
punches” towards staff to keep distance between Youth A and the
staff. Youth A was saying if staff moved closer, he would hit them.
Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4 were “huddled” around Youth A using
proximity control. Staff 1 approached and was able to secure
Youth A’s right arm and Staff 3 transitioned in and secured Youth
A’s left arm. Staff 1 and Staff 3 had Youth A in a two-person
3

restraint and were able to walk approximately ten steps with Youth
A who immediately began to deescalate, and the restraint was
released in less than one minute. Staff 1 reported Youth A did not
hit any staff outside prior or during the restraint. Staff 1 reported
Youth A has a pattern of assaulting staff who he feels he can.
Staff 1 reported he initiated the restraint on Youth A due to a
couple factors, Youth A had previously assaulted a staff in the
school approximately ten minutes prior to coming to the parking
lot, Youth A was postering toward Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4,
Youth A was swinging toward staff, Youth A has previously broken
staff car windows with rocks, staff were standing in front of Youth
A blocking rocks from being thrown, and Youth A pushed staff
who were standing in front of him. Staff 1 did not specifically
recall but thought Youth A pushed Staff 2, Staff 3, and Staff 4 four
to five times. Staff 1 reported he was also concerned as Youth A
had assaulted Staff 3 one to two weeks prior and due to Youth A
targeting staff that he feels he can assault, he did not know if
Youth A would attempt to assault Staff 3 again in this incident.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/20/2024. Staff 2 reported Youth A left the school upset and was
“explosive” and making threats that he was going to throw rocks at
car windows and assault staff if he did not get to talk to Supervisor
who was not on shift at the time. Staff 2 used proximity control
and was walking with Youth A exploring what other staff Youth A
could talk to since Supervisor was not in at the time. Staff 2
walked with Youth A for at least ten minutes trying to de-escalate
him. Youth A continued demanding Supervisor and picked up
rocks. Youth A was holding the rocks in his hand and continued
walking around. Staff 2 continued to try to talk to Youth A. Youth
A threw one of the rocks and broke a car’s back taillight. Youth A
was kicking cars and picked up another rock and threw it at a car
hitting the car tire. Staff 2 reported Staff 4 was also with him and
Youth A. Youth A continued demanding Supervisor who was not
on shift at the time. Youth A picked up another rock and threw it
toward a car however while Youth A was winding his arm to throw
the rock, Staff 2 placed Youth A in a benevolent restraint. Staff 2
reported he had Youth A in the benevolent restraint for
approximately thirty seconds. Staff 2 reported Youth A was able to
get out of the restraint he initiated as Youth A is a strong youth.
Youth A began pushing staff, Staff 2 was unsure which staff Youth
A was pushing or how many times, at which time Staff 1 and Staff
3 came and restrained Youth A in a level 1 two-person hold. Staff
2 reported Youth A was restrained for safety of himself and others
as Youth A was threatening to throw rocks at people and was
throwing rocks at cars, Youth A was puffing his chest to staff, and
4

was dysregulated. Staff 2 reported Youth A had been “volatile”
and needed to be placed in a restraint hold. Staff 2 reported he is
an Aegis Instructor, and the restraints were performed per the
Aegis techniques.
Staff 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/20/2024. Staff 3 reported he was assisting another youth and
Staff 2 and Staff 4 were with Youth A. Youth A was walking
around the parking lot with rocks in his hands saying he was going
to break things. Staff 2 and Staff 4 were following Youth A. Staff
3 went over to assist Staff 2 and Staff 4. Staff 3 believed Youth A
had thrown one rock prior to him coming over to assist. Staff 3
attempted to talk to Youth A. Youth A had a rock in his hand and
Staff 2 attempted to initiate a benevolent restraint however the
restraint only lasted approximately thirty seconds as Youth A was
able to wiggle out of the restraint as Youth A was swinging his
arms. Youth A was standing, and Staff 2 was behind Youth A,
Staff 3 was standing in front of Youth A, and Staff 4 was standing
behind Youth A next to Staff 2. Youth A was moving and swinging
his arms trying to hit Staff 3 to get Staff 3 out of the way so Youth
A could continue moving past him. Staff 3 reported Youth A did
not connect with hitting him. Staff 1 came over when Youth A was
trying to move past Staff 3 at which time Staff 1 and Staff 3
initiated a two-person restraint. Youth A was restrained for less
than a minute. Staff 1 and Staff 3 walked Youth A away from the
vehicles while in the restraint and Youth A agreed to talk at which
time Youth A was released from the restraint and walked with
Staff 1 and Staff 3. Staff 3 reported Youth A was restrained due to
having rocks in his hands, being unsafe, and pushing staff.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/28/2024. Staff 4 heard on the radio Youth A left the school.
Staff 4 went to the parking lot area and was with Youth A and Staff
2. Youth A was making statements he was going to “bust up
cars”. Youth A threw a rock at Staff 4’s car, the rock hit Staff 4’s
car however did not cause any damage. Youth A threw another
rock and it hit a car and busted the taillight. Staff 4 was unsure
how many rocks Youth A threw. Youth A began walking toward
170th Avenue. Staff 2 and Staff 4 were using proximity control by
standing in front of Youth A. Youth A began pushing Staff 2 and
Staff 4 to try to get through them. Youth A then began swinging
his fist. Staff 4 believed Youth A hit Staff 2 however he stated he
was unsure if the punch connected with Staff 2. Staff 2 and Staff
4 initiated a two-person restraint and were attempting to talk to
Youth A. Youth A was resisting the restraint. Staff 4 reported the
restraint lasted less than two minutes. Staff 4 did not recall all the
5

details of the restraint or what other staff were present. Staff 4 did
not recall if other staff took over the restraint from him and Staff 2.
Staff 4 reported the rocks Youth A was throwing were all different
sizes ranging from quarter size to baseball size rocks. Staff 4
reported the restraint was initiated due to Youth A escalating and
becoming physically assaultive by swinging toward him and Staff
2. Staff 4 reported Youth A had just assaulted Staff 7 in the
school prior to coming outside. Staff 4 reported this was not
normal behavior for Youth A. Staff 4 reported he did not know
what would have happened if he and Staff 2 would have stepped
back when using proximity control with Youth A when Youth A
began pushing and then swinging his fist toward Staff 2 and Staff
4. As Staff 4 talked through the restraint and incident, Staff 4 then
recalled Staff 1 and Staff 3 did take over the restraint as Staff 3
has a rapport with Youth A. Staff 4 did not recall Youth A getting
out of the restraint with him and Staff 2. Once Staff 1 and Staff 3
took over the restraint, Staff 1 and Staff 3 walked Youth A away.
Staff 4 did not know when Youth A was released from the
restraint.
Restraint 2:
Interviews:
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/20/2024. Youth A reported he was recently restrained in the
classroom. Youth A was told to leave the classroom by Principal
due to cussing and to go to the regroup room -RTC (Resource
Thinking Class). Youth A reported he did not want to go, and he
began flipping tables. Youth A was placed in a two-person hold
by Staff 5 and Staff 6. Youth A reported Principal had the other
youth in the class leave the classroom when Youth A flipped the
table. Youth A was restrained after the youth left the classroom.
Youth A was restrained for approximately three minutes and for
the first two minutes Youth A was resisting the restraint by kicking
and trying to get out of the restraint. Youth A did not recall falling
during the restraint. Youth A reported he was restrained for
flipping tables. Youth A was not injured during the restraint.
Youth C was unable to be interviewed as she is currently in a
psychiatric hospitalization and there are concerns for her
mental health at this time.
Youth D was interviewed via telephone on 4/15/2024. Youth D
reported Youth A became upset in the classroom and Staff 5 and
Staff 6 were following Youth A around in the classroom. Youth A
was flipping desks and trying to break the white board in the
classroom. Staff 5 and Staff 2 placed Youth A in a two person
6

hold by securing Youth A’s arms. Youth D reported he was taken
out of the classroom and did not see any other parts of the
incident.
Staff 5 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/20/2024. Staff 5 reported Youth A received RTC which is a tool
used to have youth go to a separate classroom to allow time to
calm down. Youth A was refusing to go to RTC. Staff 5 explained
female youth are on the left side of the classroom and male youth
are on the right side of the classroom. Youth A was going over to
the female side of the classroom. Youth A was told by the teacher
to go to RTC for not following the rules of staying on the male’s
side of the classroom. Youth A began flipping desks and was
cussing. Staff 5 and Staff 6 felt the situation was unsafe. Youth A
started to walk to the door and flipped a table. Staff 5 reported he
did not let Youth A leave the classroom and was using proximity
control as he was unsure what Youth A would do if he got out of
the classroom. Staff 5 did not recall who else was in the
classroom at this time and believed the teacher had already left
the classroom. Staff 5 did not recall Principal coming into the
classroom. Staff 5 reported Youth A was restrained by him and
Staff 6 when Youth A “charged” toward the door. Staff 5 was in
front of the door and Staff 6 was outside the classroom door. Staff
5 initiated the restraint and he and Staff 6 had Youth A in a two-
person level 1 restraint and described the restraint as he and Staff
6 being on each side of Youth A with Youth A’s arms out. Staff 6
switched to a level 2 and then Staff 5 and Staff 6 transitioned to a
level 4 as Youth A was resisting the restraint. Staff 5 reported
while Youth A was resisting the restraint, Youth A fell to the
ground taking Staff 5 to the ground. The restraint was disengaged
at this time. Youth A got up and went toward the TV screen and
kicked it at which time Staff 5 and Staff 6 reengaged the restraint.
Staff 5 reported Youth A was not swinging at staff but was
pushing/shoving to get past staff. Staff 5 reported when Youth A
got up from the ground, he had closed fists and Staff 5 felt the
situation was unsafe resulting in Staff 5 and Staff 6 reengaging the
restraint. Staff 5 reported this was the first time he has restrained
Youth A. Staff 5 reported the initial restraint was initiated because
staff felt Youth A was unsafe as Youth A charged the door and
flipped tables. Staff 5 reported he did not know what or why Youth
A was trying to leave the classroom for. Staff 5 reported the two
restraints he completed with Staff 6 were per Aegis technique.
Staff 6 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/20/2024. Staff 5 and Staff 6 responded to Principal’s call for staff
to be around due to Youth A being upset. Staff 5 and Staff 6 were
7

standing outside the classroom. Staff 6 reported Youth A was
upset then he was asked to go to the male’s side of the
classroom. Youth A began to escalate and was trying to kick the
TV, threw a desk, and pushed tables around the classroom. Staff
6 reported he and Staff 5 entered the classroom and initiated a
two-person Aegis restraint for the safety of Youth A and others.
Youth A was resisting the restraint and Staff 5 and Staff 6
maintained the restraint hold and moved around in the hold per
the trained Aegis technique. Staff 6 reported he almost fell twice
however did not recall falling in the restraint with Youth A. Staff 6
reported while maintaining the restraint hold, he was attempting to
verbally de-escalate Youth A. Staff 6 reported Youth A was
restrained for safety as Youth A was throwing and pushing items
in a confined classroom where there were other youth and a
teacher. Staff 6 reported there were multiple other issues
occurring in the school at the same time. Staff 6 reported Youth A
was more physically aggressive toward property, not staff. Staff 6
was concerned Youth A would throw something and it would hit
someone. Staff 6 recalled initially he and Staff 5 were waiting for
the hallway to clear prior to the restraint to take Youth A down to
RTC however when Youth A went to walk out of the classroom,
there were other youth in the hallway and Youth A was told to
wait.
Principal was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/28/2024. Principal reported Youth A was upset as she redirected
him to his side of the classroom. Boys are on one side of the
classroom and girls are on the other side. Youth A had been on
the girl’s side. Youth A was told to go to RTC. Youth A refused to
go to RTC and began stating he was going to “tear the place up”.
Youth A picked up a desk and tipped it over. Youth A was pacing
in the classroom and at one point “lunged” toward Principal.
Youth A was making statements he was going to break the TV in
the classroom. Principal reported at this time it was only her, the
classroom teacher, and other youth in the classroom. Principals
reported she called for staff to assist. Two staff came, Principle
was unsure who the staff were, and placed Youth A in a restraint.
Principal reported Youth A was restrained as he was being
physically aggressive toward staff. Staff attempted to use verbal
de-escalation prior to the restraint however Youth A became
physically aggressive as Youth A was hitting staff and “lunging”
his body towards staff. Principal got the teacher, other youth, and
herself out the side classroom door as it was not safe in the
classroom. Principal did not recall Youth A going toward the
classroom door to leave and coming back into the classroom.
Principal reported Youth A did not physically touch her however
8

Principal felt unsafe based on Youth A’s actions of throwing the
table. Principal reported Youth A “lunged” at her prior to staff
arriving to the classroom to assist. Youth A’s body did not make
contact with Principal’s body. Principal did not recall if Youth A
attempted to hit her at any time during the incident. Principal
reported if Youth A did attempt to hit her, he did not make contact.
Principal reported when Youth A gets made, he gets physically
aggressive, and it is “scary”.
The complainant is the Facilities Assigned Licensing
Consultant as the incident reports were reviewed during
weekly restraint reviews.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of 3/12/2024 in the parking lot was unable to be
reviewed as the facility does not have cameras outside.
Video footage of 3/13/2024 in the classroom was reviewed on
3/20/2024. The teacher was at the back of the classroom Youth A,
Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D were sitting at desks. Staff 5 was
standing in the front of the classroom. Youth A threw something at
the white board, got up and walked to the whiteboard/TV at the
front of the classroom and threw another object appearing to be a
folder at the TV. Principal entered the classroom through the door
and Staff 6 was standing outside the classroom doorway. Youth D
was standing in the doorway. Youth A walked toward the door
and grabbed a desk that was next to where Principle was walking
into the classroom and pushed it over. Youth A walks through the
doorway, where Staff 6 was outside the doorway, Youth D was
standing next to the doorway, Staff 5 followed Youth A, and
Principal was standing inside the classroom doorway. Youth A
turned around and came back through the classroom door. Staff 5
initiated a restraint and Youth A resisted the restraint. Staff 6
entered the classroom and assisted Staff 5 in securing Youth A in
a two-person hold. Youth A was resisting the restraint and
appeared to be pulling away from Staff 5 and Staff 6. Staff 5 and
Staff 6 continued to hold Youth A in the two-person restraint and
moved with Youth A. During the restraint Youth A used his legs to
try to trip Staff 5. During the restraint, Principal was standing in
front of the TV with a radio. Youth B exits the classroom and Staff
8 comes into the classroom. Youth A continued to try to use his
legs to trip Staff 5 and Staff 6. Youth B was walking round the
classroom and then exited through the classroom door. Youth A,
Staff 5, and Staff 6 fall to the ground as it appeared Youth A
intertwined his leg with Staff 5’s leg. Youth A was released from
the restraint. Youth A jumped up quickly as did Staff 5 and Staff
9

6. Youth A was swinging his arms. Staff 6 had a hold of the back
of Youth A’s sweatshirt and Staff 5 and Staff 6 reengaged Youth A
in a two-person restraint.
Documents Reviewed:
• Michigan Department of Health & Human Services Incident
Report 177100232 dated 3/12/2024: Youth A was walking
around the Holbrook parking lot. Youth A picked up a rock
and threw it at a vehicle in the parking lot. Youth A hit one
vehicle breaking the brake light at the top of the back
window. Youth A picked up another rock and threw it in a
different direction. Staff were aware of an incident within
the school approximately thirty minutes prior where Youth A
had assaulted a staff member in the hallway. Youth A was
throwing rocks all over the parking lot around people. Staff
2 initiated a benevolent restraint. Staff 2 was unsuccessful
at achieving the hold. Staff 3 and Staff 4 used proximity to
keep Youth A from grabbing another rock. Youth A pushed
staff several times. Staff 1 initiated a benevolent restraint.
Staff 1 transition into a two-person level one hold with Staff
3.
• Michigan Department of Health & Human Services Incident
Report 177250229 dated 3/13/2024: Youth A was being
disrespectful to the teacher and not following expectations
as Youth A was going on the girl’s side of the classroom
and received RTC as a result. Youth A became angry,
escalated and refused to go to RTC. Youth A started
flipping tables and kicking things. The classroom was full
of students and for the safety of others, Staff 5 and Staff 6
initiated an Aegis Level one restraint. During the restraint
Staff 5 and Staff 6 transitioned into a level 4. Youth A was
pushing while shoving staff and fell to the ground pulling
Staff 5 and Staff 6 with him. Staff 6 disengaged the
restraint. Immediately after staff disengaged Youth A
started assaulting staff, swinging at them and continued to
grab objects in the room and throw them around. For the
safety of others, Staff 5 and Staff 6 re-engaged a level one
restraint.
• Michigan Department of Health & Human Services Incident
Report 177240231 dated 3/13/2024: Is consistent with
Michigan Department of Health & Human Services Incident
Report 177250229 dated 3/13/2024.
10

• Eagle Village Incident Reported for Youth A dated
3/12/2024: The incident report slightly differs from Michigan
Department of Health & Human Services Incident Report
177100232 dated 3/12/2024, this incident report documents
Staff 2 was successful for approximately 30 seconds in the
benevolent restraint before Youth A was able to get out of
the restraint.
• Eagle Villate Safety Plan for Youth A dated 2/26/2024:
Youth A is being placed on a safety plan for staff to
maintain close observation due to Youth A going out of
bounds on 2/27/2024.
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedures Therapeutic Holds: When staff have attempted
to help the youth de-escalate without the success of the
youth returning to a safe and regulated state; the use of a
Therapeutic Hold may become necessary to keep the youth
safe. The only approved therapeutic hold techniques are the
methods and techniques taught in the required Aegis course
and should only be used when a resident is a serious threat
of safety or violence to self or others and/or after all verbal
de-escalation and behavior support techniques have been
exhausted.
• Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5’s personnel file:
Staff 1 had one discipline dated 3/9/2021 for an unwarranted
restraint. Staff 3 has two disciplines however unrelated to
restraints. Staff 2, Staff 4, Staff 5, and Staff 6 have no
discipline in their personnel files. Staff 1 completed the
required Aegis physical refresher training on 2/8/2023, Staff
2 on 3/1/2024, Staff 3 on 11/8/2023, Staff 4 on 3/6/2024,
Staff 5 on 3/6/2024, and Staff 6 on 11/8/2023.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as restraint 1 and restraint 2
with Youth A were found to be unwarranted per the licensing
definition based on interviews and video review of the restraint
with Youth A in the classroom and per interviews with staff
regarding the restraint in the parking lot.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered for the facility train/educate staff
on using proximity control or standing in front of youth when youth
are escalated as youth may push staff however this does not fall
under severely aggressive behavior that places the youth or
others at serious threat of violence or injury if no immediate
intervention occurs warranting a restraint. Technical assistance
was provided to the facility to ensure that all staff receive annual
11

(twelve months from date of last training) Aegis physical and
verbal refresher training.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established (previously cited under 400.4159)
SIR2023C0000125 dated 1/9/23, CAP Approved 1/23/2023
Rule Code Health status assessment; notification; debriefing; reporting.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4163
Section (5) An agency will provide an incident report on a form prescribed
Description by the department for each incident involving the use of seclusion
or restraint. The initial report shall be submitted to the department
within 24 hours of the incident occurring. A final incident report
shall be submitted no later than 72 hours after the incident has
occurred.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Restraint incident reports were not entered into MiSACWIS within
24 hours and approved within 72 hours.
Investigation Documents Reviewed:
• Michigan Department of Health & Human Services Incident
Report 177250229 dated 3/13/2024 at 1:15pm was entered
into MiSACWIS on 3/14/2024 at 5:14pm and approved in
MiSACWIS on 3/19/2024.
• Michigan Department of Health & Human Services Incident
Report 177240231 dated 3/13/2024 at 1:20pm was entered
into MiSACWIS on 3/14/2024 at 5:20pm and approved in
MiSACWIS on 3/19/2024.
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedures Incident Reports: The RTS must enter the
incident into MiSACWIS within a timely manner.
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedures Therapeutic Holds: The RTS (or designee)
must submit the initial incident report to the department
within 24 hours after the incident occurred. This IR will be
approved within the state record system within 72 hours of
the incident.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as the facility did not
complete the incident reports on the form prescribed by the
department within 24 hours of the incident occurring and the final
incident report submitted within 72 hours.
Conclusion Violation Established
12

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.

sir_summary.summary: The report details two separate incidents where a youth (Youth A) was physically restrained by staff at Eagle Village - Hainley House. The state investigation found both restraints to be unwarranted, as the youth's behavior (throwing rocks, flipping tables, pushing) did not meet the legal threshold of 'severely aggressive behavior' creating a 'serious threat of violence or injury' required for emergency restraint. The facility also failed to submit required incident reports within mandated timeframes. Culpability lies with the facility for improper application of restraint protocols and administrative failures, marking a repeat violation.
